title: G-network
summary: In queueing theory, a discipline within the mathematical theory of probability, a G-network (generalized queueing network,[1][2] often called a  Gelenbe network[3]) is an open network of G-queues first introduced by Erol Gelenbe as a model for queueing systems with specific control functions, such as traffic re-routing or traffic destruction, as well as a model for  neural networks.[4][5] A G-queue is a network of queues  with several types of novel and useful customers:
